childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1980-1992

You were born the year Ronald Reagan won the presidency and John Lennon was shot outside the Dakota. The hostages were still in Iran. Mount St. Helens had just blown its top. CNN launched, beginning the 24-hour news cycle that would eventually consume everything. America was anxious, angry, and about to swing hard to the right.

Your childhood happened during peak Cold War paranoia. The Soviet Union was the existential threat. Nuclear war wasn't abstract—you watched The Day After and had nightmares about mushroom clouds. 'Duck and cover' drills were serious business. The Berlin Wall was a permanent fixture of the world map, and nobody expected it to fall.

You were six when the Challenger exploded. Your whole class watched it on a TV wheeled into the classroom. Christa McAuliffe was supposed to be an inspiration. Instead, you learned early that sometimes things go catastrophically wrong on live television while adults stand there looking helpless.

Reagan was president for most of your childhood. You probably didn't understand the Iran-Contra scandal, but you absorbed the vibe: optimistic rhetoric, complicated reality. 'Morning in America' played on TV while crack devastated cities and AIDS killed thousands while the government said nothing.

Your toys were Transformers, G.I. Joe, Cabbage Patch Kids. Your cartoons were He-Man, Thundercats, and Saturday morning lineups that existed purely to sell action figures. Your movies were E.T., Ghostbusters, Back to the Future. Your childhood was bright plastic and synth soundtracks, all of it designed to distract from the Cold War simmering in the background.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Gen X

You're Gen X, born between 1965 and 1980. You're the tail end—the youngest of your cohort—which means you share traits with both Gen X and the Millennials who came after. You're about 65 million people in the US, sandwiched between the massive Boomer generation and the even more massive Millennials.

Gen X is the forgotten generation. You're small enough to be overlooked, skeptical enough not to care. While Boomers lecture and Millennials complain, Gen X just gets stuff done and doesn't expect recognition for it. You were latchkey kids, raising yourselves while your parents worked or divorced or both.

The defining trait of Gen X is independence born from neglect. Your parents were busy. The culture didn't coddle you. You learned to entertain yourself, manage yourself, and expect nothing from institutions that didn't notice you. This made you self-reliant in ways that younger generations find alien.

Your generation's cultural touchstone is irony. You came of age during the Reagan years, watched the culture wars heat up, and responded by refusing to take anything too seriously. Sincerity was for suckers. Cynicism was armor. You trusted nothing and expected nothing, which made you remarkably resilient when things went wrong.

Being the youngest Gen X means you bridge two worlds. You remember life before the internet, but you adopted it young enough to be fluent. You're analog by birth and digital by choice. You can navigate both worlds, which makes you useful in ways people don't always notice.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

You were born the year The Empire Strikes Back came out—the good Star Wars movie, the one with the twist. Darth Vader's revelation wasn't spoiled on the internet because the internet didn't exist. Cultural moments could still be genuinely surprising.

Music in 1980 was peak post-disco chaos. Pink Floyd's The Wall was everywhere. Blondie's 'Call Me' dominated the charts. AC/DC released Back in Black. Queen and David Bowie hadn't yet made 'Under Pressure,' but they would next year. The synthesizer was taking over, and hair was getting bigger.

Your childhood soundtracks were Michael Jackson's Thriller, Prince's Purple Rain, Madonna's everything. By middle school, hair metal ruled: Bon Jovi, Def Leppard, Guns N' Roses. By high school, grunge killed hair metal overnight. You watched Kurt Cobain make everyone suddenly embarrassed about their spandex.

TV in your childhood was three networks plus PBS. You watched The Cosby Show, Family Ties, and Cheers. MTV launched when you were one, and by the time you were old enough to watch, it still played music videos. You remember when 'I want my MTV' meant something.

Your adolescence was Nirvana, Pearl Jam, Soundgarden. Your college years were the late '90s—third-wave ska, nu-metal, the Backstreet Boys existing in parallel universes. By 1999, you were old enough to have a fully formed musical identity that the Y2K-era pop couldn't touch.

Movies defined your generation: Ferris Bueller's Day Off, The Breakfast Club, Pretty in Pink. John Hughes understood teenagers in ways adults usually don't. You saw yourself on screen—bored, sarcastic, smarter than the adults around you, uncertain about everything.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

You were born before the personal computer revolution but young enough to catch it. The IBM PC came out when you were one. The Macintosh launched when you were four. By the time you were old enough to care, computers were becoming household items, not science fiction.

Your first video game was probably Atari. You lived through the video game crash of 1983, then the NES resurrection in 1985. You were five when Super Mario Bros. came out. By middle school, you'd graduated to Sega Genesis, arguing with kids about whether Sonic or Mario was better.

The internet arrived during your teenage years. You were fifteen when Netscape Navigator launched. You were in high school when people started getting email addresses. By college, AIM existed, and you had a screen name you'd later be embarrassed about.

You graduated into the dot-com boom. You watched people your age become millionaires from websites that made no sense. You probably worked at a startup, or knew people who did, or at least read about them in Wired magazine while the bubble inflated.

Cell phones became common when you were in your early twenties. You remember when they were just phones—no cameras, no apps, no internet. The iPhone came out when you were 27, already a working adult with established habits. You adapted, but you weren't defined by it.

Your relationship with technology is pragmatic. You learned it, you use it, but you're not enchanted by it. You remember the before times. You know that human connection existed without screens, that entertainment existed without algorithms. This gives you perspective that younger people sometimes lack.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were six when the Challenger exploded. You were nine when the Berlin Wall fell. You were eleven when the Soviet Union collapsed. The Cold War—the defining anxiety of your parents' entire adult lives—ended when you were still a child. You inherited a world that was supposed to be post-conflict. That didn't last.

You were eleven during the first Gulf War. You watched CNN's green night-vision footage and saw war become television. It was fast, clean (on camera), and America won. This shaped expectations that wouldn't survive contact with later wars.

You were thirteen when the World Trade Center was bombed the first time. Most people forgot about it. You were fifteen when the Oklahoma City bombing happened—domestic terrorism, Americans killing Americans. The illusion of safety cracked but didn't shatter yet.

You were nineteen when Princess Diana died. You were twenty during the Clinton impeachment saga, watching adults argue about whether lying about an affair was worse than the affair itself. The culture wars were heating up, and nothing was off-limits.

You were twenty during the Columbine shooting. You'd already graduated high school, but it still felt like a before-and-after moment. Schools became places where bad things happened. Metal detectors and lockdown drills followed.

You were twenty-one during Y2K, which turned out to be nothing. You were twenty-one when the dot-com bubble burst, erasing wealth and optimism simultaneously. You were twenty-one during the contested 2000 election, watching the Supreme Court decide the presidency while everyone argued about hanging chads.

You were twenty-one during 9/11. Old enough to be a full adult. Old enough to enlist, if you wanted. Old enough to understand exactly how much the world was about to change. The wars that followed lasted your entire adult life. Some are still going.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You entered the workforce around 2002, after 9/11 and the dot-com bust. The economy was shaky. The optimism of the late '90s had evaporated. You started your career in a world that had just been reminded that stability is an illusion.

Your generation is the one that actually changed jobs when companies stopped offering loyalty. Gen X invented the 'free agent' mentality—not because you wanted to, but because employers made it clear they'd lay you off the moment quarterly earnings dipped. You adapted. You stopped expecting gold watches.

You've worked in offices without ping pong tables. Your career predates 'unlimited PTO' policies and standing desks. You remember when work-life balance meant leaving the office at 6pm instead of 8pm. The hustle culture that came later feels like a scam to you because you've seen the alternative.

You were twenty-eight during the 2008 financial crisis. You were established enough to survive but young enough to take a serious hit. You watched younger people (Millennials) enter a destroyed job market while you held onto whatever you had. You became the middle manager, the bridge between executives who remembered the old economy and new hires who'd never seen one that worked.

Remote work wasn't invented by COVID, but COVID made it stick. You'd already spent years proving you could work without someone watching you. The pandemic just gave everyone else permission to do what Gen X had been doing quietly: getting stuff done without performative presence.

You're in your peak earning years now. You have institutional knowledge that's increasingly rare. You're expensive, which makes you vulnerable. You've seen enough layoffs to know that experience and loyalty mean nothing when the spreadsheet needs balancing.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

You're the generation that met people in person, dated without apps, and got married because it's what people did. You probably met your partner at school, at work, through friends, or at a bar—the old-fashioned way, which is now called the old-fashioned way.

Your generation normalized divorce. Your parents divorced at record rates, and you grew up watching marriages end. This made you either terrified of commitment or pragmatic about it. You saw that forever sometimes means ten years, and that's okay.

You communicated by phone before texts, by letter before email. You remember waiting for someone to call, watching the phone, not being able to reach anyone once they left the house. The constant connectivity of modern life still feels excessive to you.

Dating apps arrived after you were already partnered, mostly. You missed the swipe era. You're simultaneously grateful and curious. Your single friends have horror stories. Your married friends have stability. Everyone wonders what they missed.

Your friendships survived distance because you learned to maintain them before social media made it easy. You write actual emails. You make phone calls. You visit people. The performative friendship of Instagram likes and birthday posts feels hollow to you because you remember when friendship required effort.

You're probably dealing with aging parents now. Gen X is the sandwich generation—caring for elderly parents while raising kids or supporting adult children who can't afford to launch. You're stretched thin, and nobody's writing think pieces about your struggles because that's not what Gen X does. You just handle it.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You were twenty-one when the dot-com bubble burst. Twenty-eight during the 2008 financial crisis. Forty during the COVID-19 economic collapse. You've seen the economy implode repeatedly, but you also saw the good times in between. You're not as shell-shocked as Millennials because you remember when things worked.

You probably bought a house. Maybe not your dream house, maybe not in your dream city, but homeownership was still possible when you came of age. You might be underwater on it, or you might have equity. Either way, you got in before the door slammed shut.

Your financial strategy is quiet accumulation. You max out your 401(k), you have an emergency fund, you don't talk about money because that's vulgar. You learned from your parents' mistakes—the credit card debt, the living beyond means—and you've been cautious. Maybe too cautious.

You watched younger generations get blamed for not buying houses they couldn't afford, for not investing money they didn't have. You know the game changed. You got lucky on timing. Anyone who says otherwise isn't paying attention.

Retirement is a real possibility for you, which puts you ahead of Millennials and Gen Z. But Social Security's solvency concerns you. You're planning to work longer than you want to, just in case. The safety net your parents relied on might not hold your weight.

Your relationship with money is practical. You're not flashy. You're not minimalist. You're just careful. You've seen boom and bust. You know that financial security can evaporate overnight. You act accordingly, even when it makes you seem boring.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your biggest weakness is dismissiveness. Gen X's signature move is not caring, which works great as armor but poorly as a strategy for change. You've gotten so good at expecting nothing that you sometimes accept less than you deserve.

You're skeptical of collective action because you've seen it fail. You watched the idealism of the '60s curdle into the greed of the '80s. You don't trust movements, institutions, or promises of change. This makes you resistant to manipulation but also resistant to genuine progress.

Your independence is sometimes just isolation wearing a different mask. You learned to take care of yourself because nobody else would, and you've internalized that lesson so deeply that asking for help feels like weakness. It's not. It's how communities work.

You've adapted so well to broken systems that you sometimes forget they're broken. You've normalized corporate dysfunction, political gridlock, and cultural decay. You've gotten so good at coping that you've stopped questioning whether coping should be necessary.

Your ironic distance keeps you safe but also keeps you disconnected. Everything's a joke. Nothing's worth getting too invested in. This protects you from disappointment but also prevents you from experiencing genuine enthusiasm. Somewhere along the way, you forgot how to be earnest without cringing.

You think younger generations are soft because they complain. But complaining is how change happens. Your stoicism isn't virtue—it's resignation. Sometimes the appropriate response to injustice is outrage, not a shrug and a sarcastic comment.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (2000-2010): You started your career in the shadow of 9/11 and the dot-com bust. You probably job-hopped more than your parents did, chasing opportunities in a suddenly uncertain economy. You might have bought a house before 2008, which was either brilliant or disastrous depending on timing. You watched the housing market collapse and learned that 'safe investments' aren't always safe.

Your 30s (2010-2020): This was your establishment decade. You built careers, families, equity. The economy recovered, mostly. You became the responsible adults you swore you'd never become. You had kids (maybe), got promoted (probably), and started worrying about things like school districts and retirement accounts. The distance between you and younger generations widened.

Your 40s (2020-2030): You're in this decade now. COVID hit when you were forty, disrupting everything you'd carefully built. Your kids are teenagers or approaching it. Your parents are aging. You're in middle management or senior positions, with all the political complexity that entails. This is peak earning, peak responsibility, peak sandwich-generation stress. You're tired, but you don't complain because that's not what Gen X does.

Your 50s (2030-2040): Your kids will launch (hopefully). Your parents may need care or may be gone. You'll be thinking seriously about retirement—when, where, whether you can afford it. The youngest workers won't understand your references. You'll be the old-timer, the one who remembers how things used to work before everything was automated or outsourced.

Your 60s and beyond (2040+): Retirement, if the numbers work. You'll be 65 in 2045, eligible for whatever Social Security still exists. You'll have lived through the digital revolution, climate change acceleration, and political realignment. You'll remember when phones were attached to walls, when the Soviet Union existed, when the future felt optimistic. Younger people won't believe you. You won't blame them—you barely believe it yourself.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're part of a birth cohort of roughly 3.6 million people born in 1980. The entire Gen X generation is about 65 million people in the US, making it the smallest generation between Boomers and Millennials. You've been overlooked your entire life, which is fine. You don't need the attention.

Compared to Baby Boomers (born 1946-1964), you're less idealistic, less numerous, and less wealthy. Boomers grew up with expanding prosperity. You grew up watching that prosperity concentrate at the top. Boomers expected the system to work for them. You never did.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996), you're slightly more cynical and significantly more financially secure. You bought houses when they were affordable. You entered the workforce before the Great Recession. You got in before the door closed. This isn't virtue—it's timing. But you're tired of being blamed for closing the door.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012), you're prehistoric. They've never known a world without smartphones. You've never known a world with them for most of your life. They're digital natives. You're digital immigrants who became fluent. The gap feels bigger than it probably is.

Your life expectancy is around 78-79 years. You're healthier than previous generations in some ways (less smoking, more fitness awareness) and less healthy in others (obesity rates, mental health). You're the generation that normalized therapy, though you still probably feel weird about going.

You're the middle child of generations—overlooked, independent, skeptical, resilient. You don't expect recognition. You don't expect thanks. You just keep showing up, doing the work, and watching younger generations discover problems you've been dealing with for decades. That's fine. You're used to it.

year_events: John Lennon shot outside the Dakota
